text:
"maybe we could create a public repo just for these install files, and the teams could clone it and pull for updates, or even change branches and pull for the steps?"

If we all agree I can create the `canton-onboarding` PUBLIC repository and add the files. First I thought that the branching idea would be good, but I think it is much easier to have one main branch and folders. Since we can manage the documentation much easier in the main README.md. We also can handle the issues as Github Issues so it can be more async for some cases. Otherwise we can ping each other on Telegram.

The only question where do they upload the output files?

text:
yeah, the upload part answers the first question as well: the only problem with a single-branch repo solution, is that steps are 'incomplete' until the previous one is ready for everyone. So imagine that we have to push before every step. And they need to pull! Would lead to confusion.
Better to somehow not show them a step until its ready, so they cant fuck it up

elements.text:
yeah, the upload part answers the first question as well: the only problem with a single-branch repo solution, is that steps are 'incomplete' until the previous one is ready for everyone. So imagine that we have to push before every step. And they need to pull! Would lead to confusion.
Better to somehow not show them a step until its ready, so they cant fuck it up

text: So I would recommend a repo with branches for steps. Then, we can tell them to checkout a branch once we put all necessary files on the relevant branch.

elements.text: So I would recommend a repo with branches for steps. Then, we can tell them to checkout a branch once we put all necessary files on the relevant branch.

text: That would make sense, but in this case it is pretty hard to reuse it on mainnet again.

elements.text: That would make sense, but in this case it is pretty hard to reuse it on mainnet again.

text: yeah, i would make a new repo for mainnet :smile: just to be on the safe side

just to be on the safe side

text:
<https://github.com/DLC-link/canton-onboarding-testnet/tree/step0/step0>

I just finished the step0. It took time, because I just wrote a lot of other things which is more like general info.

Once the node operator opens this markdown, they have to click navigate to the prerequisites by clicking on the "properly here." section. If they navigate back to the /README.md it will tell them how they can get canton client binary. On the misc/README.md they can setup the 5002 and 5001 locally. On the stepX/README.md they can run the actual Scala scripts. I think it is much easier for everyone, because the different steps are much easier to debug in case of failure.
I also modified the <http://CreatePartiesAndUser.sc|CreatePartiesAndUser.sc> so it is more verbose and fault-tolarent. If the party exists, just get it and try to create the user.
I added a <http://Validate.sc|Validate.sc> which we can use to Validate whether the node operator set it up properly.

<@U088UV6MKFE> <@U05FU0HPZ9T> Let me know what you think. It is private yet, so I did not prublish it.

If they navigate back to the /README.md it will tell them how they can get canton client binary. On the misc/README.md they can setup the 5002 and 5001 locally. text:
I finished the step1: <https://github.com/DLC-link/canton-onboarding-testnet/tree/step1/step1>
It takes time because I try to understand it as well.

I have a question for the Key generation. <https://github.com/DLC-link/canton-onboarding-testnet/blob/step1/step1/01_GenerateKeys.sc>
This generates two files where the `participant-id.bin`  is always the same even if I run it multiple times. But the `attestor-public-keys.bin` always changes when I rerun the scala script. Wouldn't it make sense so the Scala script recognize that it is already created and just get back the value? So if any of the node operators rerun it multiple times that won't be a problem.

elements.text: I finished the step1:

It takes time because I try to understand it as well.

I have a question for the Key generation.
This generates two files where the
participant-id.bin
is always the same even if I run it multiple times. But the
attestor-public-keys.bin

always changes when I rerun the scala script. Wouldn't it make sense so the Scala script recognize that it is already created and just get back the value? So if any of the node operators rerun it multiple times that won't be a problem.

text:
Hi <@U092B2GUASF>,

We are currently focusing on the testnet launch. The main runbook we have right now is located under the "CBTC Testnet launch runbook" tab in this channel. At the moment we are in a pretty good position where most of the node operators are already upgraded to the latest version on testnet which is `v2.0.0-rc.6`. You can check this in the <https://status.dlc.link/>, scrolling down to the testnet.

Also most of them are replied that they want to participate in the Canton attestor feature. Who replied back we sent them out the Step 0 which is creating the Party and Canton user for the attestor. The runbook has a table where we mark who ready with certain steps.

The next will be to run the Step 1 which uploads the Bitsafe specific dars and generate keys. In this part we will need a bit bigger cooperation, because we need to collect files from the node operators.

The current state:
• P2P just replied on TG, so I will reach write down that they also need to update to the latest version on testnet.
• Meria and Kiln did not reply nor update.
